bibl.title: Letter from Henry Hanson to Henry Rose Carter, May 29, 1922

div1.p: Hanson writes that he has announced to the press and government that yellow fever has been eradicated along the coast.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Hanson to Henry Rose Carter, May 29, 1922
div1.opener:
DIRECTOR GENERAL
HENRY HANSON
M. D.
BAJO LOS AUSPICIOS DEL
GOBIERNO PERUANO Y LA
JUNTA INTERNACIONAL DE
SANIDAD DE ROCKEFELLER
FOUNDATION
I. H. B
Hanson
Campaña Sanitaria contra la Fiebre Amarilla en el Perú
OFICINA CENTRAL
AVENIDA PIEROLA 545 - TELEFONO 3428
LIMA -- PERU
May 29,1922.
NUMERO
___
Dr. H.R. Carter,
Asst Surgeon General, U.S.P.H.S.,
2121 California Street, N.W.,
Washington, D.C.
My daer Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
In my last letter I failed to acknowledge your
reprint “A NOTE ON THE SPREAD OF YELLOW FEVER IN HOUSES”, for which I
thank you very much. Had it not been for the sad fact that my interpretor,
or perhaps it should be, translator, died recently, I should also have this
translated so as to have quite a collection your writings in the spanish.
As II notice this is an only copy so I will take good care not to lose it.
I am trying to get Karl to copy it. It will give him good practice in
using the typewriter and at the same time get me a copy of your article.

I have also received your paper on the epidemics of 1919 and
1920 in Piura which I naturally find very interesting, and correct as
your writings always are. In as much as I am hoping to embark for the
states not later than two months from today I will wait to discuss your
paper and the last epidemic until I see you. There are many points which
will make interesting comparison.

I have announced to the press and to the different Legations
that I think yellow fever is a thing of the past on this coast. We are
now getting togather the last data on our work. In my last letter to you
I believe that I estimated the total number of house visits at about
1,500,000, and also made the same statement to Dr. Rose. I am afraid that
this is a little too high. They were fully 800,000, up to the end of the
year 1921, and we have worked quite intensively in some places for five
months more, in many for two or three months, so I presume that 1,200,000
will be closer to the correct figures. There was a lot of work which at
first was not properly recorded so even though we thought we were well
organized this year there is much data lacking for the full final report.

I notice that you are keeping quite busy, with lectures, and
writing articles, and the history of Yellow Fever. I am trying to get
things lined up so that I can soon begin to dedicate myself to getting
my outline worked out at least.

I am somewhat surprised at Caldwells suggestion of carriers in
yellow fever. I did not know that any men who had experience in the work
took such suggestions seriously. Some of these people have asked about it
but we have had absolutely no evidence that there could be such a thing.
All the late cases have had a perfectly reasonable explanation, and the
suspicious cases reported which have not proven to be genuine, have failed
to present symptoms which would tend to puzzle the man who knows yellow fever.
If Caldwell had a genuine case after six months I am willing to bet that he
had others of a mild unrecognized type “tambien”. Furthermore you can not
always be dead sure that even on the haciendas they tell you “the truth, the
whole truth and nothing but the truth, So help you God”, this for more rea-
sons than one.

What you say about Africa is mighty interesting, let us hope that
you are right,- if so we can soon gather for the last rites of “yellow Jack”.

You say that up to May 1, you had received no letters since Feb.
I have written several both in March and April, some long detailed ones.
Well must close, with the warmest regards from us all,
